docs.snippet: Enron's undoing may turn out to be both a blessing and a curse for rival energy traders. While more than a dozen energy traders have hundreds of millions of dollars of outstanding claims against Enron, Enron's ruin is likely to mean new profits fo...
docs.lead_paragraph: Enron's undoing may turn out to be both a blessing and a curse for rival energy traders. While more than a dozen energy traders have hundreds of millions of dollars of outstanding claims against Enron, Enron's ruin is likely to mean new profits for rivals that could make Enron's i.o.u.'s look like pocket change, analysts and some executives said. ''We are one of the companies that will pick up the slack if Enron ceases to exist,'' said Eric van der Walde, executive vice president for trading and marketing at American Electric Power of Columbus, Ohio. ''But there are a lot of people who are going to be hurt very badly by this.''
docs.abstract: Enron Corp's undoing has mixed effects on rival energy traders; many have outstanding claims against Enron that will probably never be paid; but vacuum left in energy trading will generate new profits for traders who fill it (M)

headline.main: Energy Rivals; A Price to Pay For Opportunity

docs.snippet: At least three top White House advisers involved in drafting President Bush's energy strategy held stock in the Enron Corporation or earned fees from the large Texas-based energy trading company, which lobbied aggressively to shape the administrat...
docs.lead_paragraph: At least three top White House advisers involved in drafting President Bush's energy strategy held stock in the Enron Corporation or earned fees from the large Texas-based energy trading company, which lobbied aggressively to shape the administration's approach to energy issues. Karl Rove, Mr. Bush's chief political strategist; Lawrence B. Lindsey, the top economic coordinator; and I. Lewis Libby, Vice President Dick Cheney's chief of staff, all said in financial disclosure statement released on Friday that they already had or intended to divest themselves of holdings in Enron, the nation's leading trader and marketer of electricity and natural gas, as well as holdings in other energy companies.
docs.abstract: At least three top White House advisers involved in drafting Pres Bush's energy strategy hold stock in Enron Corp, nation's leading trader and marketer of electricity and natural gas, or earned fees from Enron, company which lobbied aggressively to shape administration's approach to energy issues; Karl Rove, Bush's chief political strategist, Lawrence B Lindsey, top economic coordinator, and I Lewis Libby, Vice Pres Dick Cheney's chief of staff, all say in financial disclosure statement that they already have or intend to divest themselves of Enron holdings; Enron was one of largest contributors to Bush's presidential campaign; its chairman, Kenneth L Lay, has close ties to Bush; administation's energy strategy suggests that federal government exercise more power over electricity transmission networks, longtime Enron goal (M)

headline.main: Bush Advisers On Energy Report Ties To Industry

docs.snippet: Enron Corporation, the world's largest marketer of power and natural gas, said it planned to generate electricity on barges off the coasts of New York, Connecticut and Massachusetts during periods of high demand this summer.    Enron, which is bas...
docs.lead_paragraph: Enron Corporation, the world's largest marketer of power and natural gas, said it planned to generate electricity on barges off the coasts of New York, Connecticut and Massachusetts during periods of high demand this summer. Enron, which is based in Houston, is studying the idea and discussing it with regulators, Shelly Mansfield, a company spokeswoman, said yesterday. A decision could be made within a few months, she said.
docs.abstract: Enron Corp plans to generate electricity on barges off coasts of New York, Connecticut and Massachusetts during periods of high demand this summer (S)

headline.main: Metro Business; Generating Power at Sea

docs.snippet: Three months after the Indian state of Maharashtra canceled the Enron Corporation's plan to build a $2.8 billion power plant outside Bombay, the state government began formal talks today on reviving the project.         Both sides are said to be h...
docs.lead_paragraph: Three months after the Indian state of Maharashtra canceled the Enron Corporation's plan to build a $2.8 billion power plant outside Bombay, the state government began formal talks today on reviving the project. Both sides are said to be hoping that a new deal can be worked out quickly, perhaps by the end of this month, to end what has been a damaging chapter in India's faltering efforts to attract foreign investment. If the plant is built at close to the scale originally envisioned, it will be by far the biggest single foreign investment ever made here.

headline.main: Talks Seek to Revive Enron Power Project in India

docs.snippet: In his Congressional testimony last month, Jeffrey Skilling, Enron's former chief executive, offered a primer on the misuses of stock options. Options, he said, are the most egregious way for companies to pump up their profits artificially. They a...
docs.lead_paragraph: In his Congressional testimony last month, Jeffrey Skilling, Enron's former chief executive, offered a primer on the misuses of stock options. Options, he said, are the most egregious way for companies to pump up their profits artificially. They also netted him a tidy $62.5 million in 2000 and helped Enron pay no income taxes in four of the last five years. Stock options, in theory, aren't a bad idea. By giving employees the chance to buy a company's stock in the future at today's price, corporations can provide an extra incentive for hard work and can augment compensation. The New York Times Company awards options to its top executives. But like other rational business practices that got out of hand during the boom years of the late 1990's, options have been abused by some companies and are in need of reform.
docs.abstract: Editorial comments on misuse of stock options, contending that like other rational business practices that got out of hand during boom years of late 1990's, options have been abused by some companies and are in need of reform; holds Jeffrey Skilling, Enron's former chief executive, in his Congressional testimony last month, offered primer on misuses of stock options; holds good place to start would be for Congress to end conflict between how tax laws and accounting rules treat options
